canvases.label: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides , f.62v

metadata.value: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 1 of 4. Travel notes by Alexander Campbell. Campbell was born in 1764 in Tombea in the Highlands, and although he studied medicine in Edinburgh, he never practiced, instead working in Edinburgh as a music teacher. He also travelled Scotland collecting traditional songs, as these notes describe. Portions of these notes pertaining to Mull were recently published in 2000 by Jo Currie in _Mull: The Island and its People_. This four-page excerpt from the notes describes Campbell’s visit with Leut Donald MacCrimmon, “the celebrated performer on the Great Highland Bagpipe”. MacCrimmon is associated with the famous piping college in Borreraig on the Isle of Skye, although when Campbell visits, MacCrimmon is living in Kirktown near Bernera Barracks in Glenelg. This first page states that Campbell carried letters of introduction from two of MacCrimmon’s friends, the Sheriff of Wist and Captain McLeod of Guesto. It also describes MacCrimmon as “a sort of Chieftain” in the area who is physically imposing, even in his older age. One of the songs collected during this visit is Cameron’s Gathering, Campbell’s manuscript transcription of which is available under LA.II.51 and has been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides, f.63v

metadata.value: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 3 of 4. Travel notes by Alexander Campbell. Campbell was born in 1764 in Tombea in the Highlands, and although he studied medicine in Edinburgh, he never practiced, instead working in Edinburgh as a music teacher. He also travelled Scotland collecting traditional songs, as these notes describe. Portions of these notes pertaining to Mull were recently published in 2000 by Jo Currie in _Mull: The Island and its People_. This four-page excerpt from the notes describes Campbell’s visit with Leut Donald MacCrimmon, “the celebrated performer on the Great Highland Bagpipe”. MacCrimmon is associated with the famous piping college in Borreraig on the Isle of Skye, although when Campbell visits, MacCrimmon is living in Kirktown near Bernera Barracks in Glenelg. On this page, Campbell describes MacCrimmon’s own playing. He says that he first “put on his hat – (his usual custom)” before playing a brilliant prelude and “Failte Phrionnsah”, in tones that spoke to the ear and affected the heart.” Campbell also notes that “the manner in which he moves his fingers seems peculiar to himself - the effects he produces, by this means, are admirable.” Campbell concludes these observations by stating, “Are the talents of MacCrimmon doomed to decay in solitude? This veteran, _in a double sense_, as the _seventh in succession_ of the MacCrimmons of Skye – his brother John, is older than he – but is now by reason of his great age, unable to perform”. One of the songs Campbell was to collect during this visit is Cameron’s Gathering, Campbell’s manuscript transcription of which is available under LA.II.51 and has been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides, f.64r

metadata.value: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 4 of 4. Travel notes by Alexander Campbell. Campbell was born in 1764 in Tombea in the Highlands, and although he studied medicine in Edinburgh, he never practiced, instead working in Edinburgh as a music teacher. He also travelled Scotland collecting traditional songs, as these notes describe. Portions of these notes pertaining to Mull were recently published in 2000 by Jo Currie in _Mull: The Island and its People_. This four-page excerpt from the notes describes Campbell’s visit with Leut Donald MacCrimmon, “the celebrated performer on the Great Highland Bagpipe”. MacCrimmon is associated with the famous piping college in Borreraig on the Isle of Skye, although when Campbell visits, MacCrimmon is living in Kirktown near Bernera Barracks in Glenelg. On this page, Campbell relates how, after leaving MacCrimmon’s home, he returned to the Public house in the village and was joined by Alexander Bruce, the Piper of Glenelg. Campbell says that “over a glass”, Bruce “communicated to me many interesting particulars regarding the mode of training pipers, by his celebrated Preceptor, which I have taken notes of; & may hereafter prove useful.” A new entry then begins on this page for 13th Oct. Campbell describes setting out before day-light and makes reference to him being lame. He says that he was attempting to take a shortcut that morning, but alludes to the fact this shortcut was to turn out to be “a rough, savage, backless wild”. The digitised excerpt concludes here. One of the songs Campbell collected during this visit to MacCrimmon is Cameron’s Gathering, Campbell’s manuscript transcription of which is available under LA.II.51 and has been digitised.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: A Slight Sketch of a Journey Through the Highlands and Hebrides
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 2 of 4. Travel notes by Alexander Campbell. Campbell was born in 1764 in Tombea in the Highlands, and although he studied medicine in Edinburgh, he never practiced, instead working in Edinburgh as a music teacher. He also travelled Scotland collecting traditional songs, as these notes describe. Portions of these notes pertaining to Mull were recently published in 2000 by Jo Currie in _Mull: The Island and its People_. This four-page excerpt from the notes describes Campbell’s visit with Leut Donald MacCrimmon, “the celebrated performer on the Great Highland Bagpipe”. MacCrimmon is associated with the famous piping college in Borreraig on the Isle of Skye, although when Campbell visits, MacCrimmon is living in Kirktown near Bernera Barracks in Glenelg. On this page, Campell alludes to recent disappointments that MacCrimmon had experienced “in some project of a similar nature to that which [Campbell has] undertaken”. Nonetheless, Campbell says that as he had “come such a distance to hear [MacCrimmon] perform on his favorite instrument; and converse with him concerning the theory and practice of the Great Highland bagpipe”, MacCrimmon sent for Alexander Bruce, “piper of Glenelg, a favorite pupil of [MacCrimmon’s] own, who played several pieces”. One of the songs Campbell was to collect during this visit is Cameron’s Gathering, Campbell’s manuscript transcription of which is available under LA.II.51 and has been digitised.
metadata.label: Description
